00174 
00175 // We use a delay in serial_printf if the string to be printed comes withing 2/3
00176 // of the maximum buffer length. The 2/3 and the delays were determined empirically
00177 // to prevent the test code from stepping on the usart buffer. If you are certian that
00178 // you won't send serial_printf strings greater than the buffer size and that you won't
00179 // use the serial_printf to send long strings more frequently than about 20ms then you 
00180 // can remove the if() condition. We have this as the default condition for the serial
00181 // library since we assume the users are novices and might miss a note to avoid long or
00182 // frequent use of the serial_printf function.
00183 /*#if defined(BUTTERFLY)
00184 #include ".\butterfly\butterfly.h"
00185 #define serial_out(val1, val2) {printf_P(PSTR(val1), val2); if(usart0_transmit_buffer_inuse_count() > ((2*USART0_TRANSMIT_BUFFER_LEN)/3)) delay(20);}
00186 #else
00187 #define serial_out(val1, ... ) {printf_P(PSTR(val1), __VA_ARGS__); if(usart0_transmit_buffer_inuse_count() > ((2*USART0_TRANSMIT_BUFFER_LEN)/3)) delay(10);}
00188 #endif*/
00189 
00190 void serial_out(const char *fmt, ...);
